results.title: Boston Symphony Orchestra
results.brief_description: The Boston Symphony Orchestra in Japan in 1960, conducted by Charles Munch and Aaron Copland, includes performances of sections of major works with narration kept to a minimum. Includes complete movements or sections from the following: Easley Blackwood Jnr - “Symphony No. 1”; Hector Berlioz - “Symphony Fantastique”; Aaron Copland - “The Tender Land”; Claude Debussy - Symphonic Poem “La Mer”.

results.title: Bossing
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Plumbing”.
Instructional film demonstrating the skill of bossing - flowing or drifting of lead from one part of sheet to another by blows from hardwood instrument.

results.title: Bossa pop
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Wolf Koenig and Sheldon Cohen
results.brief_description: Three animated figures, a man, a woman and a child, dance, arms and legs flying, to the compulsive rhythms of this Bossa Pop. A light film in carnival mood - who can remain still when the music commands? A film without words.

results.title: Bosnia at war: we are all neighbours
results.creator_credit: Granada Television International, London Weekend Television and Debbie Christie
results.brief_description: Part of an award winning trilogy which focuses on war from a humanist rather than a political perspective. The conflict in Bosnia-Hercegovina has divided families and friends. The area, once a famous tourist haven has suffered under a terrible war in the ‘90’s. This program looks at two women who have been neighbours for many years; one is Muslim, the other Catholic. Their friendship is under constant strain due to the civil unrest in their village, and yet, though fragile, it continues to endure. Other stories focus on the hardships individuals face during the conflict such as lack of supplies and family seperation.

results.title: Borrowed faces
results.brief_description: Covers the audition process at the 1979 Colorado Shakespeare Festival from the viewpoints of the actors and directors. The actors’ feelings about acting, about themselves and the roles they play are examined, as well as how they handle rejections; the directors talk about how they decide which actors to cast in which roles. The final scene shows the successful actors playing the roles for which they auditioned.

results.title: Boro's ballet: the making of an Australian ballet 1939-1961
results.creator_credit: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia, National Library of Australia, Jean Wein, Sally Jackson and Michelle Potter
results.brief_description: ‘Boro’s Ballet’ focuses on the life of Edouard Borovansky (1902-1959) and on his dream of establishing an Australian ballet company. Borovansky, a former dancer with the Paris-based Russian Ballet Company Ballet Russes, moved to Melbourne and established a ballet academy and the Borovansky Australian Ballet in 1939. In 1960 Peggy van Praagh, a former dancer and choreographer with the Royal Ballet of London, inherited the company from Borovansky. It was renamed the Australian Ballet Company in 1962. The documentary follows his early struggles to establish a school, and pays tribute to his outstanding dancers. It features rare footage of the company in rehearsal and on stage from the 1940s to 1959. This co-production between Screen Sound Australia (National Film and Sound Archive) and the National Library of Australia comprises rare professional and amateur footage and other materials and memorabilia from their collections.
results.title_for_label: Boro’s ballet: the making of an Australian ballet 1939-1961

results.title: Borneo's cathedral of trees
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation and Richard Brock
results.brief_description: David Attenborough goes in search of wildlife in the Borneo jungle, and finds the world’s largest flower; night creatures such as the tarsier, the slow loris, and the pangolin; and the nomadic Puran tribe who hunt for food using deadly blowpipes. Suitable for upper primary and secondary years 7-12.

results.title: Borneo
results.creator_credit: Cinegroup, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Colin Baker
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Travellers’ guide to the Orient”.
Borneo has long held a fascination for travellers because of the variety of its land forms and the multicultural communities of its population. The video explores the range of islands which make up Borneo, taking us through Sabah (the largest island) then onto Selingaan Island home of wild and beautiful turtles. In Sarawak we explore the fairy-tale palaces of the White Rajahs and take a trip down the Skrang River into the rainforests of Bako. This beautifully shot video is a stimulating introduction to the geography and people of Borneo.

results.title: Born yesterday
results.creator_credit: Columbia Pictures, S. Sylvan Simon and George Cukor
results.brief_description: Classic Hollywood comedy starring Judy Holliday and William Holden. Judy’s riotous performance as Billy Dawn, the clever ‘dumb blonde’, won her the 1951 Academy Award. Billy, her shady boyfriend and all his thugs move to a Washington hotel to begin wheeling and dealing in the political scene. To get her out of his way, and make her a little more cultured, and dignified, Billy’s gangster boyfriend (Broderick Crawford) hires Holden to teach her. Hilarious scenes and famous lines dot this film which has remained unforgettably and indelibly in the minds of audiences the world over. Based on the stage play by Garson Kanin.
